results.notes: Macro: thallus whitish-beige, rimose-areolate, with areoles up to ~1mm in diameter, separated by narrow cracks. Prothallus beige, same color as thallus surface, hard to distinguish from substrate. Thallus surface densely white-pruinose, +/- caked on to top of thallus. Micro: exciple of elongated hyphae (not rounded cells), asci cylindrical, 8-spored. Thick, well-developed algal layer below apothecia. Thallus cortex indistinct, possibly mostly composed of dead cells, in K only turning dark red locally. Spores measured 16-20 micrometers long by 5-7 micrometers wide, septum ~2-3.5 micrometers wide.

results.notes:
Found growing from under a mossy stone in a damp deciduous woods.
Fruitbody above ground to 3 cm tall. Orange-yellow at first, then orange, developing tan shades a few hours after collection. Tips concolorous. Terminal branches 1 mm thick. Thickest stem 3 mm in greatest thickness, somewhat laterally compressed. Stems appear to be slightly hollow and develop pink stains where injured.
Below-ground stems more or less rooting, initially white but soon browning.
Flesh soft and not brittle, pale but almost instantly turning pale vinaceous when exposed.
Odor none. Taste bitter.
Spores buff in mass.

results.notes:
Found on a large pile of mixed deciduous and eastern white pine wood chips.
Cap diameter to 49 mm, dry, not evidently staining
Gills close with multiple ranks of short gills which are often crinkled, yellow with rusty stains, subdecurrent.
Stipes to 43 mm long x 8 mm thick at apex, tapering and pinched at the base, dry, whitish above PV, concolorous with cap below and whitish near the base, hollow, not staining. Partial veil apical and membranous. Basal mycelium a mix of whitish and blue-green.
Flesh fibrous, pale pink, not staining.
Odor of wood chips. Taste also like wood chips with only a faintly bitter aftertaste.
Spore print rusty brown.

results.notes:
Nomenclature, regions, and problems.

These are photos of what we call “bicolor“ in western Pennsylvania.￼￼ problem is, I do not believe it matches what they call “by color “in other parts of the northeast. Absolutely maddening.

Ours always have this relatively thin stem, with a deep, purpleish red coloration. The red on the caps is identical when they are young, but fades to brown when they get older. They also have this unusual habit of growing in clumps.

The tubes are very short when it is young, but lengthen to level as a mushroom gets older. They never get “deep“, but neither do they stay shallow as some of the written descriptions would make you think.￼￼￼￼￼

The flash is creamy white in the cap, yellow in the stem, with red bug holes. The mycelium is white.

What would you call them in your region?
results.location_name: North Park, Allegheny Co., Pennsylvania, USA

results.notes:
Three fruit bodies growing separately on the same decaying hardwood log. The two larger more mature ones had flimsy watery texture; the largest one was nearly melted. I wondered about the largest one possibly representing a species of Bolbitius and I considered cutting it out of the photos. Then I read the account of P. longistriatus in Baroni’s field guide… “The cap and gills are quite soft and easily collapsing, especially if the weather is hot, reminding one of a Bolbitius species.”

The smallest one was preserved. I scoped a piece of gill from this fruit body. Found very few spores, and not many hymenial cystidia. One portion along the perimeter of smash-mounted gill showed cystidia with lower portions buried and inflated apices poking out. I took these to be cheilocystidia because of the localized way they profiled as a palisade (with gaps; see photo). No other hymenial cystidia found; so I’m wondering about the presence/absence of pleurocystidia.
results.location_name: Bear Creek Preserve, Bear Creek Twp., Pennsylvania, USA

results.notes:
Growing singly in soil near Quercus spp., Carya spp., Pinus strobus, Oxydendron arboreum, Acer sp., Kalmia latifolia and not other non-ECM hardwoods. Cap dry with a band of sterile tissue inrolled over margin of tubes. Pores pale yellow with white mouths; non-bruising. Stem dry, longitudinally ridged and bruising yellow in spots. Cap context white and bruising purplish-red immediately. Stem context white and unbruising except for yellowish areas around maggot holes. Cap surface taste not distinctive when licked. Taste of flesh not distinctive. Odor faintly fruity or sweet to slightly Pelargonium-like.

—

Mirrored on iNaturalist as observation 133743235 on September 5, 2022.

results.notes:
Macro: peritheciate lichen, appearing as black perithecia among grainy-surfaced thallus. Where it is best-developed, the thallus is rimose, with dark, flat to slightly convex thallus units. Surface is grainy and sand-colored, with underlying thallus appearing darker in color.

Micro: Periphyses measured 3-4 micrometers wide at tip, end cell often appearing slightly expanded but overall +/- cylindrical. Hymenial gelatin fairly persistent, not dissolving quickly in H2O. Thallus cortex scanty to nonexistent, indistinct. Thick algal layer appears basically at surface of thallus areole, underlain by black, carbonized layer in some placed. Involucrellum appears to extend down to the exciple base, or possibly encircles entire exciple, unsure.

Spores: 8/ascus, 6 measured: 19.3×5.7, 16.5×7.7, 19.7×6.7, 20.0×8.3, 21.5×9.6, 21.5×8.6 micrometers. All measured from within perithecia, none found outside of it, so some possibly immature.

results.notes:
Peritheciate ascomycete, appearing to be non-lichenized since there are no visible algae. Current working theory is that this is a lichenicolous lichen that has parasitized a species of epilithic Sarcogyne and that what would appear to be the thallus of the lichen is the dead thallus of Sarcogyne.

Macro: perithecia small, up to ~0.2 mm diam. at the top of the thallus surface. “Thallus” appearing beige-orange, similar color to the substrate, rimose. Thallus material grainy, without discernible layers. No algae present.

Spores: simple, hyaline, 2 measured: 17×10 and 19×10. Spores 8/ascus.

results.notes: These specimens were collected by a NJMA member. They were left on the table and I took them home. The tag says they were collected in leaf litter. The soil was clay and very dry. When fresh, they were 1-2cm. The peridium was thin, cream colored with a flush of pink. The gleba was white with a potato like texture. It had a small stipe attaching the fungus to the soil. I did not look at these fungi until the next day because I figured they were Rhizopogon. Looking at the spores under the microscope the next day, I realized that they were nothing like Rhizopogon spores but more like Russula (including amyloid reaction). My husband then took over and found this weird sequestrate Russula which does not look like a Russula at all. There are very few collections and they seem to be all from the west coast. The closest species we could find was Gymnomyces parksii, Singer & Singer .Saved for DNA
results.location_name: Green Turtle Lake, Hewitt, West Milford Twp., New Jersey, USA

results.notes:
Pileus: 2-3 cm; broadly convex to plane, becoming slightly depressed w/ very subtle umbo; surface glabrous w/ remnants of velipellus; dull gray-brown w/ slight red tinge, 1 mm whitish zone at margin w/ cortina remnants
gills: adnate, pallid to light brown
stipe: 4-5mm X 40-50mm; equal; pallid to straw yellow w/ darker fibrils at base; pruinose at apex only; no partial veil remnants observed; context pallid
odor: strongly raphanoid
Ecology: edge of a wet meadow situated between a creek and a stand of P. contorta. Several species were observed in a small area with various Salix spp. present. Elevation 3100m.

results.notes:
Found under oak in Pittsburgh PA. I thought this was T. badiceps/ferrugineus at first glance, but the brown tubes have me flummoxed. It is definitely not an old Xanthoconium, and probably is a Tylopilus based on the overall gestalt. T. tabacinus has been suggested, but that has never been confirmed in PA, let alone Pittsburgh.

No bruising if any kind. No notable odor or taste. The texture was firm and a little sticky, but not unusually so for a bolete of this age.

results.notes:
Cosmopolitan polypore. In the North End of Boise. Growing from a buried stump and roots, probably a silver maple. Several outgrows, some lateral, some as rosettes, since the stump is mostly buried.
Soft, and if you push with your finger, you get the feeling that is going to punch trough. Pores that turn brown, No stipe, rounded margins, brown flesh. Spores brown, oval, (10.8-12) x (6.2-7.4).
This is similar to G. lucidum, from the Ganoderma resinaceum clade, I believe Ganoderma polychromum.

results.notes:
Hemileccinum subglabripes.
Single young fruiting body beneath Sitka Spruce and Western Hemlock.
Cap: orangish brown, marginal tissue hanging below pore surface. Glabrous.
Pores: angular, NOT STAINING.
Stem: Bright yellow-covered in spines/scabers which are the same color initially. After drying scabers become reddish brown.
Faint reddish brown streaking at extreme base.
Harvested specimen.
Spore printed cap directly on glass slide for microscopy.
Spore print: Olive Brown.
Spores: Fusiform(pointed tips), smooth, long and large. Images of work included.
Mounted in KOH.
Spores are light yellow in KOH.
Dehydrated specimen and bagged for herbarium collection.

results.notes:
Single small fruiting beneath Sitka Spruce and Western Hemlock.
Cap: dull brownish gray, deeply corrugated margin.
Stem: gray overall with chevrons. Enlarged toward base.

Harvested specimen and dehydrated for herbarium collection.

results.notes:
Single mature/dry specimen in moss beneath Sitka Spruce and Western Hemlock.
Cap: light brown margin finely wrinkled. 2cm wide.
Gills: rusty brown.
Stem: violet cast with distinctive banding. 5cm long.
Odor: slightly sweet, honey.
Harvested the specimen.
Spore printed cap directly on glass slide for microscopy.
Spore print: rusty orange/brown.
Spores: LARGE, football shaped verrucose to heavily verrucose.
Dehydrated/bagged specimen for herbarium collection.

results.notes:
Found growing from under our fence. It’s been very rainy and humid here in Georgia. Lots of mushroom species around, including Chanterelles. The soil contains a lot of clay. Shady location near white oak, pine trees, holly, and sweet gum.
I’m very new to mushrooms, so curious if this is a naturally black mushroom or if it’s just…rotten? Feels firm and was rooted fairly well. Can even see a second mushroom starting to grow from the base.

results.notes: Found this one alone after it’s been very rainy and humid here in Georgia. The soil contains a lot of clay. Shady location near white oak, pine trees, holly, and sweet gum. Top has scaly spots plus that big indention (possibly damaged?). White gills underneath.
